{{refimproveblp|date=January 2013}}
'''Gregory Francis Lawler''' (born July 14, 1955) is an American [[mathematician]] working in [[probability theory]] and best known for his work since 2000 on the [[Schramm–Loewner evolution]].

He received his Ph.D. from Princeton in 1979 under the supervision of [[Edward Nelson]].<ref>{{mathgenealogy|id=35826}}</ref> He was on the faculty of [[Duke University]] from 1979 to 2001, of [[Cornell University]] from 2001 to 2006, and since 2006 is at the [[University of Chicago]].

He received the 2006 [[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics|SIAM]] [[Pólya Prize (SIAM)|George Pólya Prize]] with [[Oded Schramm]] and [[Wendelin Werner]]. In 2012 he became a fellow of the [[American Mathematical Society]].<ref>[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2013-01-27.</ref>
